{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3749830,"name":"Yoav","username":"Yoav-R","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/yoav-r/{size}/270665_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-27T19:21:38.408Z","cooked":"

About a year ago, I experimented with a data-driven approach to game piece pose estimation for FRC robots. Recently, I decided to clean up the code, organize the project, and share it with the community as an open-source resource.

What It Does

This project estimates the real-world position and orientation of FRC game pieces from camera images using a fast image-matching algorithm. It’s optimized for Raspberry Pi and designed for real-world match conditions.

How It Works

  1. Preprocessing (Offline): Render thousands of labeled images in Blender and store pose metadata.
  2. Runtime (On-Robot): Capture frames → detect game piece → match against dataset → output position & orientation.

Limitations

  • Fixed camera setup (must match dataset rendering).
  • Dataset generation takes ~30 minutes.
  • Not suitable for moving cameras.

Why I Built This

I wanted to explore whether a rendered-image matching approach could provide fast and reliable pose estimation without heavy ML models. It turned out to be surprisingly effective, consistent and accurate for fixed-camera setups.

Get Started

GitHub Repo: GitHub - YoavRozov/FRC-Game-Piece-Pos-Estimation: A project describing and implementing a kind of "brute force" approach for real-time game piece position estimation for FRC
Includes setup instructions, code, and examples.

Demo

When you say not suitable for moving cameras, does that mean it stops working once the robot moves from it’s initial position?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-27T19:38:13.438Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":559,"readers_count":558,"score":131.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":506640,"topic_slug":"open-source-real-time-game-piece-position-estimation-for-frc-robots","display_username":"MetabolicCloth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33804,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/open-source-real-time-game-piece-position-estimation-for-frc-robots/506640/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3749832,"name":"Yoav","username":"Yoav-R","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/yoav-r/{size}/270665_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-27T19:41:06.693Z","cooked":"

No, that’s not what I meant. The algorithm works fine as the robot moves around the field. The limitation is that the camera must remain fixed relative to the robot’s frame. For example, mounted securely to the main chassis. It won’t work properly if the camera is on a moving mechanism like an arm or elevator, because that would change the viewpoint compared to the pre-rendered dataset.

How well does it work when the note isn’t flat on the ground? For example, let’s say it’s rotated so that the edge is facing us, or at some sort of angle.

I’m also curious how it would work with a non-symmetrical object, such as coral from this year. Do you have any examples of that?

Obviously I didnt make it, so this could be wrong, but id assume that if the note is in a position that has an image to reference to it would work fine, but if there is not any reference images for it to find, it wont be able to work.

Idk if I explained that very well

I do understand that part , but thank you for helping clarify. My question is more in regards to accuracy, particularly when the object isn’t placed on a uniform background like on a field where there would be a lot more visual noise.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-28T04:25:15.661Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":407,"readers_count":406,"score":96.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":506640,"topic_slug":"open-source-real-time-game-piece-position-estimation-for-frc-robots","display_username":"Sam","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":73369,"username":"Kade","name":"Kade Dressing","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/c57346/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63767,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8847A | PV"},"post_url":"/t/open-source-real-time-game-piece-position-estimation-for-frc-robots/506640/8","custom_user_title":"8847A | PV","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3750275,"name":"Yoav","username":"Yoav-R","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/yoav-r/{size}/270665_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-28T05:30:12.366Z","cooked":"

On non-symmetrical objects:
With a small modification, the algorithm can handle them. Instead of using four values to describe each position (c_x , c_y , w , h), I add a fifth value: angle.
This angle can be calculated in several ways, and the repository already includes an example using the 2023 Cone.
Later today, I’ll add more examples with the 2025 Coral. For this, I use an Oriented Bounding Box (via cv2.minAreaRect()) instead of a regular bounding box.

On objects at an angle or with visual noise:
What @Kade said is correct.

The algorithm assumes you already have an object detection step (either ML-based or color filtering).
From my testing, it’s fairly forgiving, even if detection isn’t perfect, the final position estimate is usually accurate within about 5–10 cm. Background clutter doesn’t significantly affect performance because the matching process focuses on the detected region (Bounding Box/ Oriented Bounding Box) rather than the entire frame.

Also, on a different note, later this week I’ll add a more comprehensive, step by step guide on how to set it up for your own needs.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2025-09-28T05:30:12.366Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":397,"readers_count":396,"score":169.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":506640,"topic_slug":"open-source-real-time-game-piece-position-estimation-for-frc-robots","display_username":"Yoav","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":63767,"username":"Sam948","name":"Sam","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sam948/{size}/261363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57373,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/open-source-real-time-game-piece-position-estimation-for-frc-robots/506640/9","custom_user_title":"Programmer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3750518,"name":"Sam","username":"Sam948","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sam948/{size}/261363_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-28T18:48:10.505Z","cooked":"

Do you have to regenerate the dataset if you change the position of the camera? For example, let’s say I move the camera to the left four inches, is there a programmatic way to apply that offset, or is regeneration of the dataset necessary?

Yea, I’m just wondering whether it’s possible to determine the position relative to the camera, and then apply an offset to the robot similar to what we do in PV.

Hello, I am also looking into 3D pose estimation for game pieces. I found this repository GitHub - aelmiger/LINE-MOD-Pipeline: Pipeline to detect the 3D pose of known objects. It builds upon the opencv implementation of the LINE-MOD algorithm.. I was wondering if your implementation does something similar and if your code has some kind of implementation of ICP. Also, I was wondering what cameras you use as in the past I have used the stream from limelight 3s which has a video quality of 320x240, which will not be sufficient.

Thanks for the link, this looks very interesting!
I’ll need a bit more time to look into that repository, but at a high level, my approach does share some similarities with LINE‑MOD.

From my basic understanding LINE‑MOD:

  1. Uses prerendered templates of the object from multiple viewpoints.
  2. Extracts features like gradient orientations (and surface normals if depth data is available).
  3. At runtime, matches these templates against the input image (RGB or RGB‑D) to find the best match.

My algorithm also uses pre-rendered templates, but:

  1. Each template is based on the object’s bounding rectangle (or an oriented bounding rectangle) in the frame.
  2. At runtime, I match the detected bounding rectangle against this dataset to find the closest match.

ICP (Iterative Closest Point):
I don’t use ICP. From my understanding it is used to align two 3D point clouds, which doesn’t apply here because my pipeline doesn’t use point clouds.

Cameras I have used:
2023: A standard USB camera, (typically used in conference rooms for online meetings)
I only have this photo and couldn’t track down the exact model.

image746×450 68.8 KB

2024: Switched to this Color Global Shutter Arducam: Amazon Link

[Update] New Documentation Site

I’ve added a full documentation site with a step-by-step guide on how to set up the project and use it for your own Robot.

Check it out here: Step By Step Guide - Game Piece Position Estimation

This guide will walks you through:

  • Setting up Blender
  • Configuring the Blender Camera
  • Generating your own dataset
  • Using the dataset for position estimation

If you decide to try it out, I’d love to hear your feedback.
